channel.title: Drafts on Nick Arner
channel.description: Recent content in Drafts on Nick Arner

item.description: Ehi Airewele - Ehi actually cold-messaged me on LinkedIn, as he was looking for a cofounder for his company, Jumbo. Jumbo is a live audio talk platform for sports analysts. I actually really don’t care for sports at all (Ehi is planning on sports as the starting point for Jumbo), but I was really impressed with Ehi. Specifically, I was impressed with the fact that he taught himself to code specifically (he was working at a VC firm up until the start of the pandemic, in which he was laid off).

Aaron Ng - Aaron is incredibly creative, and is working on several things. One of them is flock.network; a CRM that’s built on top of Twitter. Aaron went through YC earlier this year, but decided not to participate in demo day and take subsequent funding (for now) - with VC’s hitting him up all the time for requests for new features. What’s most exciting to me about Flock is the possibility of using it for hiring - my experience has been that you can find stronger candidates for jobs via Twitter than LinkedIn or AngelList.

Aaron Ng - Aaron is incredibly creative, and is working on several things. One of them is flock.network; a CRM that’s built on top of Twitter. Aaron went through YC earlier this year, but decided not to participate in demo day and take subsequent funding (for now) - with VC’s hitting him up all the time for requests for new features. What’s most exciting to me about Flock is the possibility of using it for hiring - my experience has been that you can find stronger candidates for jobs via Twitter than LinkedIn or AngelList.

Ehi Airewele - Ehi actually cold-messaged me on LinkedIn, as he was looking for a cofounder for his company, Jumbo. Jumbo is a live audio talk platform for sports analysts. I actually really don’t care for sports at all (Ehi is planning on sports as the starting point for Jumbo), but I was really impressed with Ehi. Specifically, I was impressed with the fact that he taught himself to code specifically (he was working at a VC firm up until the start of the pandemic, in which he was laid off).

Joseph Nelson - co founder and CEO of Roboflow. Joseph had a previous startup that was acquired while in DC, and is now living in Iowa with his cofounder Brad Dwyer. Their company, around 5 people now; is working on making computer vision tools. Their website allows for computer vision dataset hosting, data set augmentation (adding noise and rotation to images in a dataset to make them more robust. This helps eliminate a lot of the tedious, boilerplate code that machine learning researchers have to write when creating vision-based ML models.

Lisha Li - Lisha’s the founder Rosebud; another YC company. Rosebud lets you make “creative deepfakes” - synthetically generated photos, and digitally animated virtual humans They’re honestly pretty wild. Lisha is a math PhD from Berkley, and used to work at a VC firm. I’ve spent some time giving her feedback on the mobile demo app that they’re currently building. I’m excited about Rosebud because of how they’re making some pretty cutting edge ML techniques to work in a way that makes new creative applications possible.

Ehi Airewele - Ehi actually cold-messaged me on LinkedIn, as he was looking for a cofounder for his company, Jumbo. Jumbo is a live audio talk platform for sports analysts. I actually really don’t care for sports at all (Ehi is planning on sports as the starting point for Jumbo), but I was really impressed with Ehi. Specifically, I was impressed with the fact that he taught himself to code specifically (he was working at a VC firm up until the start of the pandemic, in which he was laid off).
